_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: Utilize MDA forms for maintenance inspections on equipment
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: piping, vales, pumps, storage tanks, nurse tanks, etc.
_prev_prog_2.Description:
Anhydrous Ammonia Storage and Handling:



Watonwan Farm Service complies with the various rules and regulations governing the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia.  Inspection, maintenance and employee training are important components of our accident prevention program.

_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: EPCRA & MN Dept of Ag Rules
_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: Contractor subject to 26 CFR Part 1910 & 40 CFR Part 68 112(r)
_prev_prog_2.CH_OtherChanges: Contractor changed FCV-4104 makeup valve to globe valve to enable better control of flow rates
_prev_prog_2.CT_OtherType: 8.6.a. was a review during a 3-year audit by contractor.  Contractor added written competency tests in 2002.
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Ammonia and acid hose hydrostat were tested by contractor.  When the reaction contractor is on site they will have in their control room equipment specifications.
_prev_prog_2.Description:
CONVERSION OF 10-34-00:



Watonwan Farm Service Company (WFS) Easton, MN location retains an OUTSIDE contractor who utilizes their own unit for the production of ammoniated polyphosphate liquids. WFS is NOT involved in the conversion process.  The contractor has provided WFS with documentation to support a mechanical integrity program, written operating procedures, safe work procedures, emergency action plan, and a training program are in place for this process.  Additionally, WFS-Easton has their own Emergency Action Plan, Incident Response Plan and other safety procedures and policies in place, including those required by the EPA under this Program.  The contractor reports that the following safeties to the process are in place:  an audible and visual alarm system will warn if pump or over-pressurization of equipment occurs.  Fisher N-550 ESV's are installed at discharge of source and at ammonia pump, and pneumatically held open during use, are capable of remote closure.  The ammonia hose used between source and pump, as well as that used for bypass, is FMH-22 double-braided, corrugated 316L SS to avoid potential rupture between these critical connections.  A standard Fisher pressure regulator is used at the pump, pressure controlled, to bypass any excess ammonia to the suction side of the pump.  A standard ammonia backcheck valve is used on the input line at the Mix Unit to prevent ammonia loss in case of hose rupture.  Pressure relief valves for the ammonia system are recertified annually by an outside vendor retained by the contractor.  These added safeties have proven effective in avoiding potential releases for the contractor as evidenced by the contractor's safety record.

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: Minnesota Dept of Ag Regulations; For conversion our contractor is subject to PSM of Highly Hazardous chemicals and has their plan with them during the conversion process

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Watonwan Farm Service Company

233 West Ciro Street

PO Box 68

Truman, MN 56088

Risk Management Plan - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Facility:



The Coop board, management and employees at Watonwan Farm Service, Easton, MN location, are committed to the prevention of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.



2. Facility Information and Regulated Substance:



The primary activity at the facility is the storage 0f fertilizers for sale to farmers. Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, handled and distributed for direct application. Anhydrous ammonia is used for crop production nutrients.  WFS-Easton also periodically retains an OUTSIDE contractor who utilizes a mobile unit for the purpose of blending anhydrous ammonia with phosphoric acid to produce a non-hazardous liquid fertilizer, 10-34-00.  WFS is neither involved in the conversion process, nor does WFS own the conversion equipment.   



The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia would be approximately 170,000 pounds in our two 18,000 gallon storage tanks; and approximately 160,000 pounds available capacity in various 1,450 and 1,000 gallon nurse tanks. The maximum quantity handled at one time would be the unloading of a tank truck holding 40,000-45,000 pounds.



This facility is not constantly manned every work day.  There are approximately 14 employees who may work on the site periodically throughout the year.  The best estimation of full-time equivalency would be 1-2 employees. 



3. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:



The facility has implemented Minnesota Department of Agriculture rules, the Standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 C

FR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia; and 40 CFR part 68 as they apply to this facility. The facility is required to conduct a semi-annual inspection of all bulk and nurse tank equipment, including load and unload equipment, and perform any needed maintenance to the equipment found during the inspections. Visual checks are to be conducted daily at the facility.



As it relates to Process two, or the conversion our contractor has provided WFS with information to support they have a mechanical integrity program in place along with written operating procedures, safe work procedures, emergency action plan and a training program. 



4. The Five-year Accident History PROCESS 1 - HANDLING AND STORAGE:  



There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have: 



a) Caused any death, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; or 

b) To our knowledge resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.





4.  The Five-year Accident History PROCESS 2 - CONVERSION OF 10-34-00 BY OUTSIDE CONTRACTOR (MIX MOBILE UNIT)



There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have:

a) Caused any death, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility in question during the conversion process; or 

b) To our knowledge resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage at the facility in question during the conversion process.  



However, the contractor has identified one NON-WFS site incident in their safety information; and therefore, in turn WFS noted this in Section 8, Process #2.  



5. The Emergency Response Program:  



The facility has:



a. A written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38 and 40 CFR 68.95. The plan includes a specific section on NH3 Releases and what to do in the event of a release.

The next annual emergency action plan training is scheduled for July 2014. Additional emergency response training is also provided throughout the year at various training sessions, including but not limited to a training session just on anhydrous ammonia held every fall.



b. Provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);



c. Coordinated with local emergency responders.



d. A Safety Data Sheet for anhydrous ammonia as part of their emergency response plan information for quick access and reference.



e. A Minnesota AWAIR (A Workplace Accident and Injury Reduction) program in place and is committed to a safe working environment as well as protection of the community in which we operate.



The Conversion Contractor has:



a.  Provided WFS with documentation confirming they meet the fourteen (14)elements under 29 CFR Part 1910 Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals and 40 CFR Part 68, Section 112(r), as well as EPA's Risk Management Plan.  Each Contractor Mix Mobile Unit carries a PSM/RMP manual. 

 

b.  A company Emergency Action Plan and a Field Emergency Procedure/Plan.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:  Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Currently, there are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation.
